data.title: Consistently use openage::util::hash_combine()
data.body:
I have tracked down 3 places that use a different hash implementation than that defined in `libopenage/util/hash.h`. However, both implementations seem to serve the same purpose, that is, combine two hashes.

For the sake of consistency it might be good to reuse that function instead of having two implementations.

The places in question are:

https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/libopenage/coord/phys3.h#L72-L74
https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/libopenage/coord/tile.h#L58-L60
https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/libopenage/pathfinding/path.h#L207-L209
## <bountysource-plugin>

Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/29807251-consistently-use-openage-util-hash_combine?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F371436&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github)** We accept bounties via [Bountysource](https://www.bountysource.com/?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F371436&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github).
</bountysource-plugin>

data.title: detect if python dependency can be resolved via non-compiled file
data.body:
Currently, the dependency chain of python stuff is created before cython invocations.

But cython can be used to compile a python file to native code as a `.so` file. This file will be loaded _before_ the same-content-but-nonnative `.py` file.

This currently leads to the problem that if some python file depends on another python file that will be compiled, the compilation depends on a compiled file, which is a circle.
#435 happened because of this and the root cause still needs a fix.

The easiest fix is probably checking if a `.so`-file has a same-named `.py` file in the same folder, then the build can simply continue.

After you can reproduce this problem, this should be done in `openage/codegen/codegen.py`.

Related: #442 (the `.so` is not removed)

data.title: Error during start of the game
data.body:
Hi everyone 

During the start with the following command : `./run` , i get these errors :  

```
kevin@kevin-Lenovo-Flex-2-14:~/openage$ ./run
INFO [py] No converted assets have been found
media conversion is required.
please provide your AoE II installation dir:
> ./AOE2
INFO [py] Game version(s) detected: Age of Empires 2: HD Edition (Version 3.x)
INFO [py] converting metadata
INFO [py] [0] palette
INFO [py] [1] empires.dat
INFO [py] using cached gamespec: /tmp/empires2_x1_p1.dat.pickle
INFO [py] [2] blendomatic.dat
INFO [py] blending masks successfully exported
INFO [py] [3] player color palette
INFO [py] [4] terminal color palette
INFO [py] [5] string resources
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "run.py", line 15, in init run (/home/kevin/openage/run.cpp:832)
    main()
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/__main__.py", line 94, in main
    return args.entrypoint(args, cli.error)
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/game/main.py", line 33, in main
    if not convert_assets(assets, args):
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/convert/main.py", line 125, in convert_assets
    for current_item in convert(args):
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/convert/driver.py", line 126, in convert
    yield from convert_metadata(args)
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/convert/driver.py", line 179, in convert_metadata
    stringres = get_string_resources(args)
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/convert/driver.py", line 75, in get_string_resources
    stringres.fill_from(read_hd_language_file(langfile, lang, enc='iso-8859-1'))
  File "/home/kevin/openage/openage/convert/hdlanguagefile.py", line 25, in read_hd_language_file
    num, string = line.split(None, 1)
ValueError: need more than 1 value to unpack
```

Any idea , how can i fix it ? thank you

data.title: texture bin packing improvements
data.body:
An implementation of texture packing, see #314. **Code review and comments welcome.**

---

Results:

```
Strategy                                              | Total pixels |   %
------------------------------------------------------+--------------+----
Checkerboard (current state)                          | 350 244 210  | 100
Binary tree packer (target aspect ratio: 1)           | 220 296 651  |  63
Naive stripe with one row                             | 216 087 516  |  62
Binary tree packer (target aspect ratio: 1 or 97/49)  | 213 799 289  |  61
Combined                                              | 202 956 009  |  58
```

---

Example images from combined result:

![330 slp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/402777/12225037/c8dbb628-b800-11e5-984d-7f352f562641.png)
(Single stripe)

![3569 slp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/402777/12225065/a0d6d878-b801-11e5-803f-e93f35b1a228.png)
(Binary tree aspect ratio 1)

![61 slp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/402777/12225074/e1e7c782-b801-11e5-8593-4f6b4254aaa9.png)

![3091 slp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/402777/12225093/8aa98fea-b802-11e5-97e4-6a79b114a992.png)
(Binary tree aspect ratio 97/49)

---

Sum up number of pixels in all PNG files:

``` python
#!/usr/bin/python3

import PIL.Image
import glob

def pixels(filename):
    im = PIL.Image.open(filename)
    return im.size[0] * im.size[1]

print("Total pixels: ", sum(pixels(f) for f in glob.glob("assets/converted/**/*.png")))
```

Also see #462.

data.title: Check for oggenc in ./configure
data.body: I just ran `./run`, tried to convert my AoE assets and got an error complaining about lack of `oggenc`. IMHO `./configure` should check for that.

data.title: move to #pragma once
data.body:
We should move to the non-standard `#pragma once` header guard instead of constructed unique preprocessor variables.

Instead of

``` c
#ifndef BLABLA_ROFL_LOL_H_
#define BLABLA_ROFL_LOL_H_
// content content content baby
#endif
```

we should simply write:

``` c
#pragma once
// content content content baby
```

[All relevant compilers support it](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragma_once) and it will be a lot cleaner and maybe even faster in some cases.

data.title: error: enable backtrace collection by default
data.body: errors lead to crashes anyway, so the collection doesn't impact performance of a crashed program :)

data.title: hacking vs hecking???
Converted HD Language files lang codes are wrong
data.body:
When reading HD Edition language files in [`openage/convert/hdlanguagefile.py`](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/openage/convert/hdlanguagefile.py#L11), the `langcode` value is passed in as a byte string (e.g. `b'en'`, `b'fr'`) [from here](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/openage/convert/driver.py#L47). The lang code is then passed through [this langcode map](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/openage/convert/hardcoded/langcodes_hd.py) to convert to a longer language code that's compatible with the output of an AoC 1.0c language file conversion.

However, the langcode_hd map uses "normal" strings and not byte strings, so trying to access the `b'en'` property fails. And we end up with `"b'en'"` in the language field in the generated language files.

Instead, langcodes should be converted to "normal" strings beforehand, so they can be used to access the `LANGCODE_HD_MAP`.

data.title: error: implicit instantiation of undefined template (while running make)
data.body:
While running make:

```
(...)/openage/libopenage/game_renderer.cpp:85:20: error: implicit instantiation of undefined template
      'std::__1::basic_stringstream<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >'
        std::stringstream ss;
                          ^
/usr/local/Cellar/llvm35/3.5.1/lib/llvm-3.5/bin/../include/c++/v1/iosfwd:126:33: note: template is declared here
    class _LIBCPP_TYPE_VIS_ONLY basic_stringstream;
```

On Mac OS 10.11.2.

data.title: convert: support HD Edition 3.x, fixes #444
data.body:
HD Edition 3.x puts language files in a slightly different place,
and uses a funny encoding for them (i.e. not utf-8).

(At least, a funny encoding for the English language files. I'm
_assuming_ that it's the same for other languages.)

Otherwise it's largely the same as non-HD.

There are some additional SLP files in the `Data/Slp` directory,
apparently dealing with UI and fires too(?). There are some extra
palette files in the `Data/` directory too but I'm not sure how they
are mapped to their relevant SLP files.

e; now with copyright years :muscle:

data.body: all builds would succeed otherwise...

data.title: convert: expand environment variables and ~ in asset path
data.body: obsoletes and closes #436

data.title: convert: don't include slp in singlefile root
data.body:
this is required until the buildsystem detects that slp is
provided by a .py file as well.

otherwise, it is calculated that the slp...so file is required for
creating all the .so files, which is a dependency loop.

this loop doesn't exist as the slp...so is just a compiled version of
slp.py.
